revised_title: Neuronal Chemosensitivity Development after Parasympathetic Ganglion Denervation in Frogs
tldr: The study investigates the development of chemosensitivity in extrasynaptic areas of neuronal surfaces after denervation of parasympathetic ganglion cells in the frog heart. The researchers found that after denervation, the whole cell surface becomes sensitive to acetylcholine, unlike in normally innervated neurons where synaptic areas alone are highly sensitive. This discovery adds to the understanding of neuronal supersensitivity and chemoreceptive areas in the nervous system.
